Tour of Britain 2023: Route, start list and all you need to know

The Tour of Britain is back. The 2023 edition of the UK’s premier men’s road race begins in Altrincham on Sunday 3rd September with eight stages around England and Wales, finishing in Caerphilly on Sunday 10th September. After the 2022 race was cut short following the death of Queen Elizabeth II, fingers crossed all eight stages will be ridden this time around.

The climbing kicks in almost straight away, with the first stage around Greater Manchester and Cheshire featuring two categorised climbs including the short but steep Ramsbottom Rake. The second has a climb with around 10km to go that should spice up the finale and it’s then pretty much flat until the final two stages. Stage 7 from Tewkesbury to Gloucester has two second category climbs, including Crawley Hill around 20km from the finish. The final stage is the hardest of all though, with four first category one climbs including two ascents of Caerphilly Mountain before finishing in Caerphilly itself.

A stacked field of riders is expected at the start including Movistar‘s 2022 winner Gonzalo Serrano, 2021 winner Wout van Aert of Jumbo-Visma and Ineos Grenadiers‘ Tom Pidcock, who was looking to challenge Serrano for the title last year before the final two stages were cancelled. It’s not just those three though, a stack of the world’s best riders and Great Britain and Ireland’s top talents will be hoping to make their mark.

Tour of Britain 2023: Key information

Dates: Sunday 3rd to Sunday 10th September 2023
Start: Altrincham, Greater Manchester
Finish: Caerphilly, Wales
UK television coverage: ITV4, Eurosport, GCN+
Television coverage elsewhere: Eurosport (Europe, Asia and Oceania), GCN+ (Europe, Asia, Oceania and North America), L’Équipe (France), RTVC (Colombia), Starzplay (North Africa), SuperSport (Sub-Saharan Africa)

Tour of Britain 2023 stage-by-stage preview

Stage 1: Sunday 3rd September, Altrincham – Manchester, 163.6km

A tough day including the 25% ramps of Ramsbottom Rake with a slightly uphill sprint finish looks like a perfect day for Wout van Aert.

Stage 2: Monday 4th September, Wrexham – Wrexham, 109.9km

The climbing on day two comes just before the end to thin the field out before a descent to the finish. Looks like another perfect day for Wout van Aert.

Stage 3: Tuesday 5th September, Goole – Beverley, 154.7km

A sprint day with a couple of kicks up on the run-in. Looks like another perfect day for Wout van Aert.

Stage 4: Wednesday 6th September, Sherwood Forest – Newark-on-Trent, 166.6km

A flat sprint stage. Looks like another perfect day for… you know where this is going.

Stage 5: Thursday 7th September, Felixstowe – Felixstowe, 192.4km

A flat sprint stage. Looks like a perfect day for Wout van Aert.

Stage 6: Friday 8th September, Southend-on-Sea – Harlow, 146.2km

See above – a flat sprint stage that looks like a perfect day for Wout van Aert.

Stage 7: Saturday 9th September, Tewkesbury – Gloucester, 170.9km

Finally, some tougher uphill tests including a couple close to the finish to either reward the breakaway or properly thin the bunch down, One last time, it looks like a perfect day for Wout van Aert.

Stage 8: Sunday 10th September, Margam Country Park – Caerphilly, 166.8km

The Queen Stage, four category one climbs including two ascents of Caerphilly Mountain before a descent to the finish. Looks like a perfect day for Wout van Aert.

For full detailed maps of each stage visit tourofbritain.co.uk

Tour of Britain 2023 TV guide

The Tour of Britain will be broadcast live in the UK on ITV4 and Eurosport with streaming on GCN+ and Discovery+ (with the same coverage).

GCN+ costs £6.99 paid monthly, or £39.99 per year and Discovery+ costs £6.99 per month or £59.99 per year for sports and entertainment (for fans of shows like Wheeler Dealers and Naked and Afraid).

Streaming coverage via GCN+ will be available in Asia, Europe, Oceania and North America.

Highlights packages will also be available on all broadcasters’ channels including ITV4 highlights shows at 20:00 every evening and short highlights will be free to watch on YouTube.

Official broadcasters

Colombia: RTVC
Europe: Eurosport, Discovery+, GCN+
Middle East: Starzplay
North Africa: Starzplay
North America: GCN+
Oceania: Eurosport and GCN+
Sub-Saharan Africa: SuperSport
UK: ITV4, Eurosport, GCN+, Discovery+
